{term}Amplitude modulation{/term} ({term}AM{/term}) of a source signal divides the signal's spectrum into two copies, with one copy shifted towards higher frequency and the other copy shifted towards lower frequency; refer to {cnxn document="m????"}AM Mathematics{/cnxn} for a complete treatment of basic AM. The shifted and dual spectrum makes an interesting special effect when applied to a musical instrument or the human voice, creating the sensation of two different people speaking the identical phrase, for example.
If one of these spectral images could somehow be cancelled out, AM seems to be a feasible way to implement a {term}pitch shifter{/term}, a device or algorithm that will shift the source spectrum higher or lower in frequency. When this special effect is applied in real-time, you can speak into a microphone and sound just like one of "Alvin and the Chipmunks." Click {link src="pitch-shift-demo.wav"}pitch-shift-demo.wav{/link} to listen to an example of what you will be able to accomplish after completing this module.

String.Val: The screencast video of {cnxn target="video-ssbshifter"/} develops the basic theory of {term}single-sideband modulation{/term} ({term}SSB{/term}), a technique borrowed from communications systems that provides a way to apply amplitude modulation with spectral image cancellation.

String.Val: As an exercise to ensure that you followed each step, draw a block diagram or flow diagram to show how the original signal is modified to produce the final shifted signal. Your diagram should include directed lines (arrows) to show signal flow, and should use symbols (blocks) for the multipliers, cosine and sine oscillators, Hilbert shifter, sign changer, and adder.

String.Val: {term}Pre-filtering{/term} the source signal to ensure the shifted spectrum does not cause aliasing is also discussed, since the source signal typically fills the available bandwidth.
